commentBody:
Me to self “hmm, I wonder why there seem to be two themey things going on”
Me to self again - “wait, what, he has a lisp?”
Me a few moments later “too bad we couldn’t have some EVOO on this puzzle”

But it was nice fun without any dressing!

A wonderful puzzle!

I was hoping to see a clue that read “Suggested time to meet at Wimbledon?” Tenish anyone?
SHINEDSHIELDDELIVERED is one of the funniest crossword answers ever. Bravo.

Why should we drink a well-made martitini? For the shake of it! 
What an entertaining, cleverly constructed puzzle! Thank you.
It was quite easy to solve but very clever and so much fun.  Loved this Sunday's puzzle!

The mini crossword 1 down clue is wrong. The movie referred to is about Greek history - the battle of Thermopylae. The answer is to do with Roman culture. In this instance, an aspect of Roman culture that they adapted from the Etruscans. 
Greetings from Sydney, Australia

Fun but easy theme. Generally good fill, but with proper nouns crossings. A few clever clues. Too easy overall. 

5/10

My collection of 007 bOOks fell on my head. I have only my shelf to blame. 

Great clue for SILENCER [“Device for cutting bangs?”].

SCRAGGY…. According to M-W a British variation of scraggly, which is the term I am familiar with. 

Congratulations on your debut, Danny.
This was a puzzle that was double fun.

66D clue: Are the circled squares 
"connected by a single line" or by two lines?

And this is not math class:
no line segment comments, please.
SO COOL! This Bond fan loved this puzzle. Thank you, Danny!!

Never heard of the kea before. After a quick google I learned they are the only alpine parrot. They look like dragons. They are intelligent, scrappy, and mischievous (many funny antics including throwing rocks at people). New favorite animal unlocked! The list is long.

007 theme was jolly good. I tip my hat to the constructor.

Truly pleasurable.   The double "o"s made some clues easy to solve but the "h" s led to lots of oohs!
Evoo was new to me.  
For those who found it too easy, bravo!  I say it's easy to make it harder with obscurantist clues, but that might come at the cost of the graceful cleverness so manifest in this puzzle.
Loved the theme. I didn’t understand the second meaning to  “could I have a ship” though, not sure what I’m missing?
Funny.

This puzzle was such a delight to solve.  The puns were funny and all of the clues for them inspired. SHINED SHIELD DELIVERED says it all.

Take a bow, Danny. I'd say you ascended the throne today with some divine help: GODS HAVE THE KING
This was such a silly theme. I absolutely loved it.

I mean, it's no STARTREK themed puzzle... (har!!!) but I liked it a lot! I enjoyed the DOUBLEOs and that they formed a seven—very fun! 

I had a lot of trouble figuring out CANIHAVEASHIP but it finally came to me before I asked it out here. The rest seemed more obvious to me—in a fun way! 

Had the hardest time finishing up PERIDOT. I am somewhat cocktail literate (MARTINI, yes please!) but did not know that one to SHAVE my life! I finally figured out that the cardinal thing was a sports ball reference and I did know that the Cards are STL. I should have gotten it sooner but I was thinking the Catholic cardinal was capitalized. I looked it up after and it would not be, as I'm sure most of you know, unless it was specifying a particular cardinal. Oops, forgot about that rule.  

Anyhow, other than that tricksy area, it was pretty fun and smooth sailing. I really enjoyed the theme entries a lot, especially SHINEDSHIELDDELIVERED!  

My only downers were that I just hate when APE shows up as imitating someone. I will have to dig deep into my psyche to figure out why I dislike it so much, but I did immediately get it. 

The other one that I cringed mightily about was SILENCER. I know the reason that one bothers me, though...  I was hoping it would be something else.  The subject of things that go bang has become increasingly unpleasant for me. 

Ohhh, but I suppose I am tiptoeing ANTLIKE into potentially questionable comment territory, so I will take my leave. 

Cheers! 🍸

A lot happening thematically, but some of the fill made me cry ACK. The simultaneous revival of both ERLE and ERN was almost too much to bear.

Thank goodness I knew PERIDOT (which shouldn't rhyme with FEEDLOT), since both KIR and EDOM were unknowns. Knowing BARI helped too.

Maybe next week we can learn about LOA, the Lithuanian porpoise who plays chess.

Perhaps doing two puzzles in one day is not for me. This one seems to have made me YOHO. In any case, APLOMB is an excellent word.
An “s to sh” phrase puzzle could also be Carol Channing themed.

A fun and clever puzzle!  Loved SHINDSHIELDDELIVERED but now the Stevie Wonder song is stuck in my head.   I thought the “sh” sounds were a hint to slurred speech after a few martinis, but Caitlin cleared that up in her column. Congratulations on a great debut, Danny!
This was like a layered torte complete with jelly between the frosting and the next layer. What a pleasure. We had puns, Sean Connery, and a connect the dot.  How fun.
With JAMES BOND, SEAN CONNERY, NICOL WILLIAMSON, and ETON, I like the chapshtick going on in the box today.
What a treat! Seven out of seven MARTINIs

The Sean Connery "quotes" were adorable, the double-o's in a seven were a clever little touch, and some bonus Bond sprinklings throughout - excellent puzzle! Some tricky fillers, but very gettable with crossers and the odd Google confirmation, as evidenced by my under-average time. Top debut crossword.
Thanks Danny, shuper Shunday sholve!

Brilliant! I’m not even halfway done with the puzzle yet, but laughed so hard that I had to come here to comment. 

The top half was an easy fill, but I was wondering what the OOs had to do with the SH words. Then I got to GOD SHAVE THE KING, and thought, that sounds like something Sean Connery would say — and OMG that’s it! I counted the number of OOs, and true enough, there were 7 of them. 

What a fantastic tribute to my favorite Bond! I’m now going back to finish the puzzle and savor every minute of this genius construction!

The theme is super cool, but the proper nouns were really antagonizing me with this one. I'm wondering if anyone else filled "A PLAN B" for "composure under pressure." It doesn't quite make sense, but I've never heard of APLOMB before.
I've never solved a more ingenius and entertaining puzzle. Congratulations!

Very proud of myself tonight. I finished this Sunday crossword in 1 hour and 5 minutes without the help of the Crossword Column, any hints at words or looking at the answer key. This is a first for me. I’m 76 and doing the New York Times puzzles each day keep my mind alert. I still miss the Vertex puzzle which was discontinued last August 29.
Great theme and excellent execution. Really enjoyed it.
I found this puzzle delightful. I admire anyone who can get a debut on their first try. I especially love the title, “A Man of Character.”  Great job, Mr. Rooney!
My 3000th completed NYT crossword intersecting with Mr. Rooney's debut.   But, of course!   Thanks for the BONDing time.
I could swear I saw that "bit of work" clue and word yesterday.
Nice. Though frankly I never noticed his "iconic accent".

Love this puzzle and theme. The clues for SILENCER, LEVEE and NOSEHAiR more than made up for having to tolerate LINTIER. The themed entries were all very fresh and funny. My only disappointment was, although you can hardly not clue MARTINI as a themed entry in a Bond puzzle, it gave a way the theme so quickly I didn’t get to ponder it more which I would have otherwise. GREAT DEBUT!
Technically 007 is written with zeroes, not Os. Yeah, I get it - good enough for a crossword bla bla.
Congratulations on a solid NYT debut, Mr. Rooney! I had fun of writing it up for Diary of a Crossword Fiend: https://crosswordfiend.com/2025/08/30/sunday-august-31-2025/#ny
debut?!!  woah - unbelievably clever and fun to do!
Besht ever.

I just happened to be drinking a glass of 72A while solving, a perfect way to celebrate my first-ever Golden Month. Oh, and guess what I had for lunch? 11D!

Had a proper Natick in the form of EDOM/PERIDOT, and found four mistakes before I could brute force the crossing. This is why I say Sunday is my highest probability of failure.

26 minute solve, but it took more like an hour, since I kept pausing every time a rally in the Bublik/Paul match went more than a couple of shots, and for all pressure points...

Brutal crossing PERIDOT/KIR/NICOL/EDOM.

😮
A stellar start, Mr. Rooney, splendid work. (I thought about playing off the theme but managed to show some restraint and reshisht the urge.)
We are not amused. May be one of the worst Sunday puzzles so far this year. Why mock how Mr Connery talks. Brutal.

Fun puzzle!!

Finished under my usual Sunday puzzle average - but had great fun doing it!

I’m working through the archives and I’m in January 1995.  (1/1/95 is a doozy! Fun and hard!). I’m always surprised by words that keep appearing back then and currently.  MACRO for one.

Loved the multiple elements of this one.
Loved this puzzle. Just brilliant.

Super fun Sunday solve! I have some gripes with the crossing of NICOL and EDOM with PERIDOT and IONA and HODGES with LEANDER, but your mileage may vary — I know better than to call something a **tick in this here comments section, and also did still manage to solve without assistance.

On the flip side, I almost feel like the revealer could have been obfuscated more! When I blind guessed MARTINI, I was so excited to fill JAMES BOND based on a clue like “Frequent drinker of 33D” — was honestly surprised to see how much 111A and 113A bend over backwards to make it clear to a solver.

Anyway, I only say this because I loved the puzzle, and wanted to spend even longer with it. A marvelous debut.
My wife and I agree this was our favorite NYT crossword puzzle ever!!! Hard to believe it was a debut puzzle! Well done! Thank you!!!

I loved this one. I remembered the first time I solved one exactly like this by Jem Burch (April 22, 2021) and it was his debut puzzle as well. It was early in my regular solving days and I thought it was the coolest thing ever. It was the first time I saw animation on a puzzle. Daniel Craig was the star of Jem’s and the magnificent Sean Connery the star of this one. Congratulations, Danny. Clever clueing and truly enjoyable solve. Looking forward to more from you!!

As @HeathieJ said, this was almost as fun as the Star Trek puzzle. I could hear Sean Connery's voice all over it!

I was wondering where the Easter egg was that Caitlin mentioned. Turns out it was "You sure," meant to rhyme with "You, sir." Does it rhyme to you all? I pronounce "sure" more like "shore." Is this regional?

FEEDLOT calls to mind the stench of bovine misery that greats you as you drive past Harris Ranch on Highway 5 in the California Central Valley. It seemed like we'd just had this entry recently, but it turns out it was in a 2023 puzzle I did this week. Made me sad to see it both times.
So much fun! Very clever.
Fun puzzle.  Had trouble with some of the proper names but really loved “shinedshielddelivered”.  Solved but a little slower than usual and one google assist.

fun sunday.
one cluing quibble:  90A...zest and peel are hardly synonyms.
zest is the outer colored part of the peel.  pith is the inner bit. ask any cook.  you never want to grate the pith into your dish.
This might be my favourite Sunday puzzle to date.
Best puzzle ever, on so many levels.

Excellent puzzle, excellenter debut puzzle.

(Hey, if "lintier" is a valid word, then "excellenter" is, too.  And oddly enough, it's showing as a red underlined misspelled word in this paragraph, but not in the first sentence.)

Really loved SHINED SHIELD DELIVERED--that was the last one I got and it was the best of a really good bunch.
Exceedingly clever--working the theme within the theme! I laughed out loud multiple times, leaving me shaken with glee, not just stirred. Bravo!

Absolutely delightful! For a beginning constructor to come up with these clever clues and the oo-soo-viaual element was impressive! I enjoyed solving this because I had a crush on Sean Connery as .007 when I was finishing high school. Gave me a nice warm nostalgic feeling. Well done, Mr. Rooney (you gotta love the Irish--I do!).
As a Bond fan, I absolutely loved this puzzle. As a Brit I had a great image of millions of Americans trying to solve clues with fake Scottish accents. Brilliant
Wait! Is it finished? I want moore! Moore, please!

Though I appreciate the skill and effort of this crossword, I am old enough to remember Sean Connery telling Barbara Walters that yes, he would slap a woman "if she needed it." It ruined the whole Bond franchise for me. Then seeing today's column headlined "A Man of Character" was a true slap in the face. Asking the Bond fans, are there better Bond portrayers to base a puzzle on ? One with a better character ?
Well having "yokel" as a casual word is indeed uncouth...
Easier than usual, but I didn't get the 007 image until I solved the puzzle. Guess that makes me sorta clueless.

Loved this puzzle.   The stack of 35A, 42A, 48A were all delightfully deceitful clues, as was 35D.     The only clue/answer that I didn't really care for was 59A (ant-like), but excepting that I enjoyed this Sunday puzzle from top to bottom.

GOD SHAVE THE KING! (You will need to MOVE YOUR ASH to do that, maybe)

I laughed out loud several times while solving this puzzle, and my wife did too when I read the themed clues and answers to her. Brilliant! Our having a soft spot for Bond movies made us enjoy the puzzle even more.

(BTW, you will probably have my ash for this, but I think Dalton was the best Bond)

Of course I needed lookups for my many unknowns, and I ended up checking the puzzle when I did not get my gold star. It turned out I had one square wrong, at the crossing of PERM_ATE and _RLE. I honestly thought the word was spelled PERMiATE (my Polishness is showing here, because that's how you'd spell the word in Polish to pronounce it the English way), and of course I did not know the writer, so iRLE for their name looked good enough.

One thing my wife and I don't get ish "Abbr. on a paper tray" sholving to LTR. Help cluelesh Polish people out, pleashe?

I had doubleo as ooseven for ages which stuck me for a while, that and the bank security misdirect, I had lever for levee. There were a couple of naticks in there but I managed to guess my way out of them. Nitpick of the day - most Americans may have an SSN memorised, most people do not
Been doing these for a while now -- is KEA part of the standard xword toolkit?
Phenomenal!

17:56 today (I average a little over 25:00), I almost finished it first time through the across clues. I should wake up too early every day. I don't need to be challenged every day, it's also fun to have a few chuckles doing these.

It’s a little-known fact, but James Bond prefers playing badminton to tennis; it has something to do with the feel of thwacking the object in the game.  It may only be a shuttle difference, but to James, it’s everything.




Et tu, emu.
Loved it!

As it happens, I have completely solved today's puzzle. Yes, I took a peek at the solution. No errors! No happy music, either. I cleared my grid, re-entered all correct answers, and still no joy. What gives? Anybody? Thanks in advance.

This was so fun. I think being british helped a little though. Also, as much as I am familiar with the Sean Connery Bond films, it's always Eddie Izzard's impressions of him in his early stand up shows (1990s) that stay in my head. Maybe the humour has dated a little by now, but Noah (as voiced by Sean Connery) speaking to God (voiced by James Mason) about turning the ark into a shpeedboat is hilarious forever. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r3LU2Ilx1GE

Danny juggled three theme elements, and all three – the connect-the-dots seven, the s-to-sh sentences, and the four JAMES BOND factoids – nestled comfortably in the box.  Impressive.

I love that the only double-O’s in the Sunday sized puzzle are the circled letters. Elegant.

And SHINED SHIELD DELIVERED?  Mwah!

Oh, all those many years ago, I couldn’t wait for the next Bond picture. I knew his quirks, loved his quick thinking and suaveness, relished the evil of his enemies, and clenched inside through all the hairy moments he faced.

My tastes have changed, but it was fun today to relive what it felt like to be me then.

A trio of pairs to note:
•	Two debuts in a row, yesterday and today, by people who have been making puzzles for less than two years.
•	The consecutive uber-memorable puzzles this week, one by a wife and the other by her husband.
•	The gorgeous crossing answers today of APLOMB and PERMEATE.

Congratulations on your debut, Danny. Thank you for a very sweet outing!
Alas, I wasted 30 min of my life because I had IDEALdATE crossing dOmp and was guessing that JFK predicted the establishment of the EtA.

The name’s BOND, JAMES BOND.
That is one shweet puzzle. Bravo Mr Rooney.

OOseven before DOUBLEO held me up a tad, but did not diminish the joy of the fill. Not the hardest Sunday grid, but definitely one of the most enjoyable.

My Dad loved the BOND franchise. I lost count of the Saturday nights spent with him and 007 on the tv. I realised while writing this that I’m now the age my Dad was when he died. That’s sobering.

I love the Sunday puzzles. i don't often complete - maybe 50% - but the sense of achievement when I do is worth it. On this occasion I feel I have nailed one of my favourite crosswords of all time. I got the 007 connections quite quickly but the italicised clues were a bit of a mystery until Shined Shield Delivered was unlocked. Totally magnificent and right up there with the best clues I've ever seen (and I've been doing crosswords for 50+ years). I've always felt that I could one day compile a decent crossword myself but this one tells me I'd rather be a solver any day. The level of skill is stratospheric. Thank you for making my day
Yet again, fun theme, but way too easy for a Sunday NYT.
Inspired puzzle.
I had OOseven for the longest time…
This was the funniest Sunday puzzle ever. Very, very clever!

Today's Mini has an inaccurate question, and thus a wrong answer for 1 Down. A wrap for the movie 300 uses toga as an answer. That movie was about Greeks at Thermopylae and Marathon centuries before Rome conquered Greece. No togas, not possible. How sloppy, NYT. I expect better.
An IRA is not a portfolio holding
Am I the only one who liked Roger Moore as 007?
This was a super enjoyable, most clever  puzzle!  Looking forward to many more from Danny Rooney.  He has a gift!

Fantashtic debut.
Shplendid.

That center spanner was worth the 
cost of admission all by itself.
Rule of thumb….do not taunt the NYT crossword editors.  Two days ago I joked in the comments about Omoo fading from memory…And today it appears.  (I have to assume out of spite) 😀

Another great debut so congrats to Mr. ROOney!

Silky smOOth but got hung up at the KIR/PERIDOT/CHE/ACK confluence.  Almost went down but managed to stay afloat.  

So I ended up stirred but not shaken.  

Nicely done.

Quick note on today’s mini.  1D clue references a film about an historic Greek, specifically Spartan, battle.  The answer is a Roman garment, not Greek.  The loosely corresponding Greek garment was a himation.

This was one of my favorite Sunday puzzles in a long time.  The theme was right up my alley and actually helped in the solve.  The concept was witty and the OO circled letters an interesting aspect.  Some nice wordplay and, at the same time, a very approachable puzzle.

Thank you Mr. ROOney for a very fun puzzle from one who has been a OO7 fan since the sixties.
Beautifully done, sneaky clues, loved finishing this, loved Sean Connery in that role, great memories. Thank you!
This was a fun one! Congrats on your debut, Danny!!

This was fun. I was moving right along, even had a sense of  how the theme worked, but when I got SHINED I couldn't tell why the answer was missing the AND, so my biggest holdup was converting sealed to SHIELD.

You'll rue the day you croshed me, Trebek!

Thanks!
Those punny entries are just spectacular. Well done Danny!
What a mesh! Indeed. Enjoyed the theme but the last 5 clues for me took 30 mins. Needed to look up Bari and Nike. So convinced it was Mali and Truman (Tinman). Didn’t like IDEALMATE but so it is.

Great puzzle. Clever and tricky. 
Now, to the NYT:
Listen, I pay a subscription for the games and I'm happy to do so. But by axing the free mini crossword you have just made MY subscription less valuable, and less attractive, because I no longer have anyone to play against every day.
You can afford to make the mini free, you cheapskates.

Thank you, Danny, for a terrific puzzle! Loved the themers. Loved hearing Connery in my head. Adored the Constructor Notes! 

So much great fill, too. Special callout to PERIDOT! (Same character count as emerald, I learned today, but as soon as I got the P from our old crossword friend ASP, I knew which green stone we were looking for!) Very apt on this, the last day of the month: PERIDOT is the August birthstone, which I know because my sister's birthday was just a few days ago. She happens to be visiting, here in BK, which makes the fill extra sweet. 

I'm not much of a fan of Broadway musicals... but with such great wordplay throughout this puzzle, I look forward to seeking out Mr. Rooney's other work! Bravo!

Well, wasn't THAT a dainty dish to set before us on this final day of  August!  I enjoyed being misdirected by the clues--even had to erase a couple of entries (SUITOR for "Beau" and APED before AGED..ahem! And I mistakenly removed IDEAL because it clashed with DOT COM, which was wrong.)  
I hope that makes you smirk happily, Mr. Rooney; you're entitled to the triumphal march.
PhysicsDaughter is here (college football season started, so The Football Buddies--DHubs and PhysDau--were glued to the TV.  Happily, Penn State did very, very well, as did Ohio State ...apparently The Big Ten are favored by this household.)  The cat and I hung out separately.  Anyway, PhysDau is still working on her copy of the puzzle.  (I have a wee smirk on my face, too.  Being AGED sometimes confers an advantage.)
Best.  Crossword.  EVER.
Quite the debut! I thoroughly enjoyed the puzzle. Well done and welcome, Mr. Rooney!

An 007-themed crossword is a lovely idea.  A lisp-themed crossword could be very nice.  Combining them?  More bang for the SILENCER?
SHINED SHIELD, DELIVERED?  Brilliant!

But today's nit, and I don't think it's a small one:
Sean Connery doesn't have a lisp! He has a Scottish (more specifically Edinburgh) accent.  That's not even close to the same thing!
I went  and listened to some scenes.  I even listened to some comedians parodying his accent.  No lisp!

Cat Lady Margaret noted that in the first comment for today's puzzle, but few others seem to care.

The fun really shtarted for me with MOVE YOUR ASH. When the theme became clear and Sean Connery showed up I was all in. A very special and highly entertaining debut IMHO. Beautifully done, Danny J Rooney!

As for 007, everyone has their favorite Bond. I do, too, but I love them all.
I didn't like it.  Too many try hard “cute” phrases and puns.  You can have a theme without creating your own jokes and obscure references.   Tarnished.
Don't know if it was intentional but the o's in the circles made them look like the gun barrel logo.

The puzzle was already exceptionally easy without the added help of the two circled "O"s.  Still, I guess you have to have them to make it possible to draw that big, big 7 -- which of course I didn't draw.

Still punch-drunk from the difficult and unpleasant trivia-fests of the last two days, I was relieved to have a puzzle that had minimal trivia and an emphasis on wordplay instead.  There wasn't much challenge, but it was mildly amusing.  I don't remember SEAN CONNERY speaking with a lisp or whatever that speech peculiarity is called, though.  To me that's a Humphrey Bogart thing.

I see that Danny is a musical theater writer.  Must take a quick peek to see if he came out of the BMI Workshop.  (He would have been there long after me, though.)  Then I'll go listen to some of his songs.  There has been such a strong tie between theater songwriting and crossword puzzles over the years,  I suspect it's the same gene -- yet to be identified.

If you ashked me to name an actor known for shwapping in SH’s for S’s, my immediate answer would be Jimmy Shtewart. 

I can shtill remember when he was in adsh in which he was shelling shoup.

Wow. Just wow. This puzzle is brilliant on so many levels - it may be the cleverest crossword I've ever seen, due to the multiple thematic elements. Well done! And thank you for a great solving experience.

In "Die Another Day" Pierce Brosnan as James Bond became quite SCRAGGY while being imprisoned in NK. But only then, so hardly ever. Of course this puzzle focuses on Sean Connery's Bond who seldom had a hair out of place.
A delightful Shunday romp
This was a lot of fun, thank you! My final guess, as always, was, what will the Wordplay headline be? I went with His Word is his Bond.

I liked this a lot. Did anyone else get initially misdirected by seeing 24A as the alternative to WHATAMENSCH, so thinking all the special clues would be words for persons of good CHARACTER? 
  Maybe the concept is on my mind these days.

Willkommen, bienvenue, welcome! I'm back!

Though I loved the Bond(Bondski in Polish) theme, the main reason I adored this puzzle is that the constructor is a musical-theater writer!

That's right-Andrzej(me) now loves musicals. I didn't think it was possible, but never say never. I spent the last few weeks in The Big Apple(whatanappleski in Polish), mostly going to Broadway musicals. I saw 18 of them, including The Lion King 007 times!

The Lion King really puts the "musical" in "family musical" but it really puts the 'family" in "family musical" and now I'm determined to have a flock of children just so I can take them to see The Lion King. I'm sure my wonderful wife will come around on this. After all, you only live twice.

(Fun fact: Sean Connery played The Man Who Would Be Lion King)

The only other thing I've been doing here is going to Mets' games with Steve. I now love baseball!(Never say never, again!) Baseball diamonds are forever! I only wish I could see Jacob deGrom throw his thunderball.

A quick note to my many followers on TikTok: I will no longer be singing hymns. From now on, I will only be singing musical-theatre songs(as well as I Am the Very Model of a Modern Major-General).

From Poland with love, so long, farewell, Auf Wiedersehen, goodbye.

Hakuna Matata!!!

Love, Anzdrej(really!)

Nice theme.  A few stumbling blocks, like for a long time I thought 71A had to be EMERALD rather than PERIDOT and not knowing what color peridots are.

Also had a couple of squares to fix at the end.  Like I had ANTLINE instead of ANTLIKE and didn't know what a KEA was, and I had IDEALDATE instead of IDEALMATE cause I'd never heard of MOET.

But I really liked the punny long clues.

Congrats to the constructor and thanks to the editors. Fun puzzle and very rewarding feeling when I finally sussed the theme. 

I really struggled, though, in one spot, not knowing PERIDOT nor three of the crosses! Yikes, four gaps in my knowledge having a little get together in the middle-left of the grid. I was left to filling in letters according to what sounds I thought humans might make. Was startled to hear the victory jingle. Perhaps later I'll settle in with a KIR royale and watch a NICOL Williamson film.
SHINED SHIELD DELIVERED might be one of my favorite entries of all time.
Besht Sunday puzzle in ages. Evoking the great Sean Connery's acshent-- a complete joy!
I rarely leave comments, but I had to express how much I enjoyed this puzzle. I raise my martini glass to the author. Cheers!
Great puzzle! I always thought it was “SCRAGGLY” and not “SCRAGGY” so that stumped me a bit

One of the Mini clues is misleading. Not only does 300 not depict accurate ancient Greek attire, but the answer is a Roman garment, not a Greek one. They should have cited Gladiator or Ben-Hur or Spartacus or one of the other million movies set in Rome.
Bravo, double 00 Rooney! Looking forward to many more of your puzzles.

I love how the OO in 85A crosses the 7 in the British/European fashion. 
I thought maybe zeros would be required in the circles, but that was not an issue.
Shaken, not stirred!

I got all but one square, and even finding out the answer, I still have no idea what the ETA of JFK's prediction is. (Although, upon reflection, I should have gotten the bubbly: MOET answer.)  

But this was a real fun puzzle to work on!
How does one connect the OOs with a single line?  (As opposed to two lines!)  Is there a trick there, or is that just poor editing?
TIL it’s HASS not HAAS
What a stunning debut! Innovative theme, masterfully executed.

Can anybody explain this to me? What does "you sure" have to do with Connery's knighthood or anything else?

"In the end, omitting Connery’s proper title felt a bit disrespectful, so I decided to add a secret theme entry with YOU SURE at 106-Across — a bridge connecting the character to the man who made him an icon. Here’s to you, Sir!"

Thx!
Great construction, fun solve! Outstanding job Danny!
For a minute I thought the straight line through the double o’s was short and depicted a toothpick through the two olives in his martini.

All I wanted was a sweet distraction for an hour or two. This Double O seven was pure heaven.

Swathi
What a wonderful debut!
How great to see all the positives!  Was so afraid I would see "too easy".  Just loved it.

What an ekshellent debut!

I got the double O's immediately, as OMOO is one of those Crossword Things you should remember. PATOOT and SMOOCH came pretty easy, and made me giggle, which is always welcome. When I reached the revealer at 111A, I oo-ed aloud!

I said earlier this week when I completed a 5-year streak that I would disclose my cheat rules. So, for anyone who cares, you can tell what kind of streak it is.

I actually have a long list, but it boils down to this. When solving on paper in the aughts, I would use any reference book to help. This included Wikipedia. It included most anything short of the answer key.

When I began solving online in 2014, I discovered that as long as I didn't do "check puzzle," if I had an error somewhere, the software would alert me but not tell me where. If I found it on my own, even by trial and error, it would give me the star. So I reformed my rules around that as a guideline. This meant not doing anything that was akin to revealing the answer, such as using search terms that would bring up the clue and answer. Other kinds of research, I still allowed myself. 

As I've become more acquainted with typical crossword fills and misdirects, I've used fewer kinds of help. This streak began about 6 years into my online solving experience and I honestly can't remember how much help I was using at that time. I can say that by now, maybe once a month I can't find a mistake and resort to verifying the spellings of my answers. If I use any word or part of a word from the clue in my search term, I consider that an asterisk in my solve. This streak includes probably four or so asterisks.

The whole Bond thing blossomed just as I was fighting my way through puberty.  I saw Thunderball probably when I was 13 or 14, young enough to think "Do people really act like that when they're naked?"

I hated Bond.  I hate the movies.  I've been told to try this one or that one and I do, and I am literally shedding tears of boredom before I'm even half-way through.

Having seen Sean Connery's Bond when I was just beginning to notice the opposite sex, he was the ultimate competitor.  As such, there was no way I could like him, or even not despise him.  So I approach Bond in every film as if he were built from the worst aspects of Satan, Pluto, and John Voight.

I wonder how it affected young people differently depending on their gender and budding sexual preferences.  Obviously many girls my age saw Sean Connery (or any Bond) in a very different light.  

But I don't recall being attracted to the glamorous sex symbols of the era designed to appeal to me:  Marilyn Monroe, Tina Louise's Ginger on Gilligan's Island, anyone reeking of pretense.  And Bond was nothing if not pretentious. 

So maybe the girls I felt I was competing with Bond over didn't like him as much as I assumed they did.

@Andrzej

Yeah, we're adopting a bonded pair (I guess that's a standard term for two dogs that have lived most of their lives together) from...inhale...the mother of a friend of my daughter who died, leaving two dogs without a home.

This coincides with the last of our dogs having died a few months ago.  It was grievous as you know, and I was sure she'd want to "re-dog" at some point.

This project, though, is exclusively my wife.  I love dogs, but to the point that think it's detrimental to my own life.  Hard to describe, but just the psychological pressure of making sure they're all right--well fed, well-exercised, not left alone for too long--all of that, worrying about them, really weighs on me.  

Another monumental failure on my part is being a soft touch for treats and a scrap from the table.  I just can't help but be melted by those eyes.

I can now see that it's I who have the problem, not the dogs.

Anyway, I still have a couple of weeks of calm and low psychological pressure.

@Francis

Wow, that's such a humane thing your wife is doing, I'm impressed.

I like caring for a dog - it gives me a sort of purpose in life. I've never had or wanted children, and I don't consider a dog a substitute for a kid (I find it weird when somebody calls themself a dog's mom or dad), but I suppose on some level a dog fills for me the same niche as offspring would.

I completely broke down when there was nothing more we could do for Jorge in July. I was an emotional wreck for a few weeks there after he passed. But for all those years before, taking care of him and providing him with the best possible care came naturally to me, and generally little stress was involved, except one cancer scare and one time when he almost died of food poisoning (he probably drank some horrible chemicals from a puddle in a forest where heavy machinery operated, dripping liquids all over the place).

A dog's health is paramount, so I never give dogs and human food, or overfeed them. If you teach a dog your food is not for them, ever, they don't beg for it, btw, so there is no opportunity to be melted by those eyes. I suppose my being rational rather than emotional in most things I do helps here, too.

@Andrzej

We have fascinating similarities.

We have even more fascinating differences.  I entirely agree with rationality of emotions, and yet...  

I totally understand that too much human food for dogs could be life-limiting.

But human food is also life-limiting for us.  Where is the balance point between long life and joyful life?

I couldn't figure it out for my diabetic mother, who I couldn't deny at least an occasional taste of chocolate.  Nor can I figure it out for my dogs.

And most obviously, I can't figure it out for myself, either.  I don't think I'm living for longevity any more.  I'm not even certain that I should.

If you have the Games app on your phone, first look at the List display. It makes it much easier to see mistakes. (That’s how I found that I had HILL where I should have had HILT.)

If that doesn’t help, I would clear the grid and retype everything again.
